revision.text:
{{infobox person/Wikidata | fetchwikidata=ALL | dateformat = mdy|list=hlist|awards={{hlist|[[Officer of the Order of Canada]]|[[Governor General's Awards in Visual and Media Arts]]|[[Governor General's Performing Arts Award]]|[[Member of the Order of Canada]]|[[Order of Montreal]]|[[Prix Albert-Tessier]]|[[Grand Officer of the National Order of Quebec]]|several [[honorary doctorate]]s}} }} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} '''Alanis Obomsawin''', {{Post-nominals|country=CAN|OC|GOQ}} (born August 31, 1932) is an [[American Canadian]] [[Abenaki people|Abenaki]] filmmaker, singer, artist and activist primarily known for her documentaries .<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.horizonzero.ca/textsite/witness.php?is=9&file=17&tlang=0|title=HorizonZero Issue 09 : WITNESS|website=www.horizonzero.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-01-20}}</ref> Born in [[New Hampshire]], United States and raised primarily in [[Quebec]], Canada, she has written and directed many [[National Film Board of Canada]] documentaries on [[First Nations]] issues.
Obomsawin's described "the basic purpose [of my films] is for our people to have a voice[...] no matter what we're talking about whether it has to do with having our existence recognised, or whether it has to do with speaking about our values, our survival, our beliefs, that we belong to something beautiful, that it's O.K. to be an Indian, to be a native person in this country."<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Gendering the Nation : Canadian Women's Cinema|last=Pick|first=Zuzana|publisher=University of Toronto Press|year=1999|isbn=|editor-last=Banning|editor-first=Kass|location=Toronto, Canada|pages=78|chapter=Storytelling and Resistance: The Documentary Practice of Alanis Obomsawin}}</ref> Her best known documentary is ''[[Kanehsatake: 270 Years of Resistance]]'', about the 1990 [[Oka crisis|Oka Crisis, Quebec]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=National Film Board |authorlink= |last2= |first2= |authorlink2= |title=Kanehsatake: 270 Years of Resistance |year=1993 |url=http://www.nfb.ca/film/kanehsatake_270_years_of_resistance/ |accessdate=May 23, 2011 |postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}} |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110430051153/http://www.nfb.ca/film/kanehsatake_270_years_of_resistance/ |archivedate=April 30, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }}</ref>
== Early life == Obomsawin was born in New Hampshire on Abenaki Territory. When she was six months old, her mother returned to the [[Odanak]] reserve north east of Montreal where she lived until she was 7. During this period she lived with her mother's sister Jesse Benedict and her husband Levi who had six children of their own.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=The Long Walk of Alanis Obomsawin|last=Alioff|first=Maurice|date=June 1987|work=Canada Cinema|access-date=|last2=Schouten Levine|first2=Susan|issue=15}}</ref> Théophile Panadis, her mother's cousin, initiated her into the history of the Abenaki Nation and taught her many songs and legends. Obomsawin and her parents then left Odanak for [[Trois-Rivières]], where they were the only Native family. Cut off, speaking little French and no English, Obomsawin held fast to the songs and stories she had learned on the reserve.
After moving to [[Montreal]] in the late 1950s, having learned English during a two-year stay in [[Florida]], she performed as a singer and a storyteller, making appearances on reservations, in prisons and schools, and at music festivals.<ref name=":0" /> She has one child, Kisos Obomsawin, born in 1969.
== Film career == Obomsawin directed her first documentary for the NFB, ''Christmas at Moose Factory'', in 1971.<ref name=Walker>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/aboriginal/alanis-obomsawin-s-trick-or-treaty-to-screen-at-tiff-2014-1.2729269|title=Alanis Obomsawin's Trick or Treaty? to screen at TIFF 2014|last=Walker|first=Connie|date=6 August 2014|work=CBC News|accessdate=6 August 2014|location=Toronto}}</ref> As of August 2017, she has directed 50 films with the NFB, with her documentary film ''[[Our People Will Be Healed]]'', about the Helen Betty Osborne Ininiw Education Resource Centre in [[Norway House Cree Nation]], premiering in the Masters programme of the [[2017 Toronto International Film Festival]].<ref name="Brownstein">{{cite news|last1=Brownstein|first1=Bill|title=There's no stopping legendary documentarian Alanis Obomsawin|url=https://montrealgazette.com/entertainment/movies/theres-no-stopping-legendary-documentarian-alanis-obomsawin|accessdate=15 November 2016|work=Montreal Gazette|publisher=Postmedia|date=10 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blog.womenandhollywood.com/tiff-2016-women-directors-meet-alanis-obomsawin-we-cant-make-the-same-mistake-twice-13856968d595#.afw4f7wbm|title=TIFF 2016 Women Directors: Meet Alanis Obomsawin — “We Can’t Make the Same Mistake Twice”|last=Berger|first=Laura|date=2016-09-15|access-date=2016-09-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/entertainment/tiff-2017-canadian-films-1.4238828|title=TIFF announces Canadian film lineup|work=CBC News|access-date=2017-08-09|language=en}}</ref>
Her previous film was the 2016 documentary ''[[We Can't Make the Same Mistake Twice]]'', exploring a [[Cindy Blackstock#Human rights complaint and Federal court proceedings|human rights complaint filed against the Canadian government]] over discrimination against First Nation children, which had its world premiere on September 13 at the [[2016 Toronto International Film Festival]].<ref name="Bambury">{{cite news|title=Alanis Obomsawin documents Cindy Blackstock's fight for equality for Aboriginal children|url=http://www.cbc.ca/radio/day6/episode-301-human-rights-in-china-u-s-open-getting-schooled-in-comedy-cindy-blackstock-and-more-1.3743693/alanis-obomsawin-documents-cindy-blackstock-s-fight-for-equality-for-aboriginal-children-1.3743703|accessdate=7 September 2016|work=[[Day 6]]|publisher=[[CBC Radio]]|date=2 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blog.womenandhollywood.com/tiff-2016-women-directors-meet-alanis-obomsawin-we-cant-make-the-same-mistake-twice-13856968d595#.afw4f7wbm|title=TIFF 2016 Women Directors: Meet Alanis Obomsawin — “We Can’t Make the Same Mistake Twice”|last=Berger|first=Laura|date=2016-09-15|access-date=2016-09-18}}</ref>
Obomsawin's 2014 documentary ''[[Trick or Treaty?]]'' was the first film by an indigenous filmmaker to screen in the Masters programme at the [[2014 Toronto International Film Festival|Toronto International Film Festival]].<ref name=Walker/> Obomsawin began conceptualizing the film in 2010 when she was invited by Stan Louttit, Grand Chief of the [[Mushkegowuk Council]], to film a conference the band was hosting about [[Treaty No. 9]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Alanis Obomsawin brings "Trick or Treaty" to Studio Q|url = http://www.cbc.ca/player/play/2640853386|website = CBC Player|date = 2014-12-17|accessdate = 2015-12-04|language = en-CA}}</ref>
Obomsawin's 2013 documentary ''[[Hi-Ho Mistahey!]]'', about [[Shannen Koostachin]], a First Nations education activist, premiered at the [[2013 Toronto International Film Festival]].<ref name="2013TIFFcbc">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/story/2013/07/30/tiff-city-midnight-docs-vanguard-lineups.html|title=Toronto film fest unveils docs, horror and Athens lineup additions|date=20 July 2013|work=[[CBC News]]|accessdate=17 August 2013}}</ref>
Her 2012 documentary ''[[The People of the Kattawapiskak River]]'' on the [[Attawapiskat First Nation#Housing and infrastructure crisis|Attawapiskat housing crisis]] was conceived when Obomsawin was present in the community in 2011, working on another film for the NFB.<ref name="Dunlevy">{{cite news|url=https://montrealgazette.com/entertainment/movie-guide/RIDM+People+Kattawapiskak+River+examines/7519138/story.html|title=The People of the Kattawapiskak River examines a community on the edge|last=Dunlevy|first=T'cha|date=9 November 2012|work=[[Montreal Gazette]]|publisher=Postmedia Network Inc.|accessdate=9 November 2012}}</ref>
In 2010, she completed a short drama ''When All the Leaves are Gone'', about her experiences attending public school in Quebec.<ref name="Playback HofF">{{cite web|title=Hall of Fame 2010: Alanis Obomsawin|last=Bailey|first=Patricia|url=http://playbackonline.ca/2010/09/09/hall-of-fame-2010-alanis-obomsawin/|work=[[Playback (magazine)|Playback]]|publisher=Brunico Communications|accessdate=November 18, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101128062252/http://playbackonline.ca/2010/09/09/hall-of-fame-2010-alanis-obomsawin/| archivedate= November 28, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
In 2009, she completed the documentary ''Professor Norman Cornett: "Since when do we divorce the right answer from an honest answer?'' looking at the dismissal of unorthodox [[McGill University]] religious studies lecturer Norman Cornett, which will have its world premiere at the [[Hot Docs]] film festival.<ref name="NFB">{{cite web|url=http://www3.nfb.ca/collection/films/fiche/?id=55837|title=Professor Norman Cornett: "Since when do we divorce the right answer from an honest answer?"|work=NFB Collections page|accessdate=March 30, 2009}}</ref><ref name="NFB pr">{{cite news|url=http://www3.nfb.ca/press-room/communique.php?id=19321|title=Notable NFB Presence at Hot Docs 2009|date=March 24, 2009|work=NFB press release|accessdate=March 30, 2009}}</ref>
Obomsawin's recent credits include ''[[Gene Boy Came Home]],'' about Aboriginal [[Vietnam War]] veteran Eugene Benedict.<ref>[http://www.nfb.ca/collection/films/fiche/?id=54549 NFB collections page]</ref> In 2006, she completed ''WABAN-AKI: People from Where the Sun Rises'' a look at the people and stories from her home reserve of [[Odanak]]. In 2005, Ms Obomsawin completed her short drama ''Sigwan'', following a young girl who is aided by the animals of the forest. Her 2003 NFB documentary ''Our Nationhood'', chronicles the determination and tenacity of the [[Listuguj Mi'gmaq First Nation]] to use and manage the natural resources of their traditional lands.<ref>[http://www.nfb.ca/enclasse/doclens/visau/index.php?mode=view&filmId=51406&language=english&sort=title NFB collections page] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927230012/http://www.nfb.ca/enclasse/doclens/visau/index.php?mode=view&filmId=51406&language=english&sort=title |date=September 27, 2007 }}</ref> The Mi'gmaq of Esgenoopetitj ([[Burnt Church]]), [[New Brunswick]] were the subject of her 2002 documentary, ''Is the Crown at war with us?'', exploring a conflict with the Department of Fisheries and non-native fishers over fishing rights.<ref>[http://www.nfb.ca/enclasse/doclens/visau/index.php?mode=view&filmId=51067&language=english&sort=title NFB collections page] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930201659/http://www.nfb.ca/enclasse/doclens/visau/index.php?mode=view&filmId=51067&language=english&sort=title |date=September 30, 2007 }}</ref>
The 2000 NFB release ''Rocks at Whiskey Trench'' was Obomsawin's fourth film in her series about the 1990 Oka crisis. The first, ''[[Kanehsatake: 270 Years of Resistance]]'' (1993), was a feature-length film documenting the 1990 Mohawk uprising in Kanehsatake and Oka, which has won 18 international awards. It was followed by ''My Name is Kahentiiosta'' (1995), a film about a young Kahnawake Mohawk woman who was arrested after the 78-day armed standoff, and ''Spudwrench – Kahnawake Man'' (1997), profiling Randy Horne, a high-steel worker from the [[mohawk nation|Mohawk]] community of [[Kahnawake]].
Obomsawin's films also include: ''[[Incident at Restigouche]]'' (1984), a powerful depiction of the Quebec police raid of a Micmac reserve; ''[[Richard Cardinal: Cry from a Diary of a Métis Child]]'' (1986), the disturbing examination of an adolescent suicide; ''No Address'' (1988), a look at Montreal's homeless; as well as ''Mother of Many Children'' (1977).
Obomsawin first came to the attention of the NFB in the mid-1960s, when she held fundraising concerts to pay for the construction of a swimming pool in Odanak. Children in her community were no longer able to swim in the [[Saint Francis River (Canada–United States)|Saint Francis River]], but were not allowed to use a pool in a neighbouring community, which was for white residents only. Obomsawin's success in raising funds for a construction of a pool for Odanak children was interviewed about it by the [[CBC-TV]]'s ''[[Telescope (TV series)|Telescope]]'' series, which was seen by NFB producers [[Joe Koenig]] and Bob Verrall.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tiff.net/the-review/for-150-years-people-have-been-told-lies-about-canadas-history/|title="For 150 years, people have been told lies about Canada's history"|last=Obomsawin|first=Alanis|date=2017-03-27|work=The Review|access-date=2017-03-28|publisher=Toronto International Film Festival|language=en}}</ref><ref name="Taylor">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/aboriginal/alanis-obomsawin-passes-knowledge-to-aspiring-filmmakers-1.2953663|title=Alanis Obomsawin passes knowledge to aspiring filmmakers|last=Taylor|first=Jillian|date=14 February 2015|work=CBC News|accessdate=20 February 2015}}</ref>
"It was from there the National Film Board (NFB) saw it and I was invited by some producers to talk to some of the filmmakers there," said Obomsawin. "I discovered that they had a studio that only catered to [the] classroom, with educational film strips."
They invited the singer/storyteller to the Film Board to work as an advisor on a film about Aboriginal people. She went on to direct films of her own, while continuing to perform and fight for justice for her people.
Obomsawin is a member of [[Film Fatales]] independent women filmmakers.
==Non-film work== In 1960, Obomsawin made her professional debut as a singer-songwriter in New York City. As a performer Obomsawin has toured Canada, the United States and Europe performing for humanitarian causes in universities, museums, prisons and art centres, as well as at folk art festivals. She also managed her own stage at the [[Mariposa Folk Festival]] in the 1960s.<ref name="Robb">{{cite news|url=https://ottawacitizen.com/entertainment/movies/alanis-obomsawin-the-power-of-art-revealed|title=Alanis Obomsawin: The power of art revealed in film|last=Robb|first=Peter|date=19 February 2015|work=Ottawa Citizen|accessdate=20 February 2015}}</ref> Her 1988 album ''Bush Lady'' featured traditional songs of the Abenaki people, as well as original compositions.
For over 25 years, Obomsawin has worked as an engraver and printmaker, with exhibitions in Canada and Europe. Mother and child imagery is prominent in her work, which also combines material from her own dreams with animal spirits and historical events. Her work was exhibited at the Maison Lacombe in Quebec in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|title=Obomsawin, Alanis - Bush Lady|url=http://citizenfreak.com/titles/294247-obomsawin-alanis-bush-lady|website=Museum of Canadian Music|accessdate=24 May 2016}}</ref>
==Personal awards and honors==
In May 2017 Obomsawin received an honorary doctorate from McGill University's School of Continuing Studies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mcgill.ca/newsroom/spring-2017-hondoc-bios|title=Spring 2017 Honorary Degree recipient bios {{!}} Newsroom - McGill University|website=mcgill.ca|language=en|access-date=2017-06-02}}</ref> That same month, she was named a Commander in the newly created Order of Montreal, recognizing individuals who have contributed to the development of Montreal.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ici.radio-canada.ca/nouvelle/1034352/ordre-montreal-375e-dany-laferriere-yannick-nezet-seguin-francoise-sullivan|title=Montréal honore Dany Laferrière, Yannick Nézet-Séguin et Françoise Sullivan|last=ICI.Radio-Canada.ca|first=Zone Société -|date=2017-05-17|website=Radio-Canada.ca|language=fr-ca|access-date=2017-06-02}}</ref> In March 2017, she received the inaugural Prix Origine at Montreal's Bâtisseuses de la Cité Awards, for her work on Indigenous issues.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vingt Montréalaises d'exception nommées "Bâtisseuses de la Cité"|url=http://www.tvanouvelles.ca/2017/03/17/vingt-montrealaises-dexception-nommees-batisseuses-de-la-cite|accessdate=24 August 2017|work=TVA Nouvelles|agency=Agence QMI|date=17 March 2017|language=French}}</ref>
In November 2016, she received the [[Clyde Gilmour]] Award from the [[Toronto Film Critics Association]], which called Obomsawin "a significant architect of Canadian cinema and culture."<ref>{{cite news|title=Alanis Obamsawin honoured with 2016 Technicolor Clyde Gilmour prize|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/entertainment/alanis-obamsawin-filmmaker-toronto-film-critics-award-1.3865468|accessdate=25 November 2016|work=CBC News|agency=The Canadian Press|date=24 November 2016}}</ref> Also in 2016, she received two of Quebec's highest honours when she received the [[prix Albert-Tessier]] for contributions to the [[cinema of Quebec]] in November,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://povmagazine.com/blog/view/alanis-obomsawin-wins-prix-albert-tessier|title=Alanis Obomsawin Wins Prix Albert-Tessier|last=|first=|date=|website=Point of View|publisher=[[Documentary Organization of Canada]]|access-date=2016-11-07}}</ref> and was named a Grand Officer of the [[National Order of Quebec]], in June of that year.<ref name="COQ">{{cite web|title=Alanis Obomsawin: Grande officière (2016)|url=https://www.ordre-national.gouv.qc.ca/membres/membre.asp?id=3335|website=Ordre national du Québec|publisher=Gouvernement du Québec|accessdate=7 September 2016}}</ref>
In October 2015, she received a lifetime achievement award from Chile's [[Valdivia International Film Festival]].<ref name="Mango">{{cite news|last1=Mango|first1=Augustin|title='Motu Maeva' Wins at Chile's Valdivia Film Festival|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/motu-maeva-wins-at-chiles-831216|accessdate=7 September 2016|work=Hollywood Reporter|date=10 October 2015}}</ref> In February 2015, the Montreal-based arts peace advocacy group Artistes pour la paix presented her with its lifetime achievement award.<ref name="le devoir">{{cite news|title=Les 7 doigts de la main nommés Artiste pour la paix|url=http://www.ledevoir.com/culture/actualites-culturelles/432029/les-7-doigts-de-la-main-nommes-artiste-pour-la-paix-2014|accessdate=7 September 2016|work=[[Le Devoir]]|date=17 February 2015|language=French}}</ref> In March of that year, she was among the first 35 people named to the inaugural [[Ordre des arts et des lettres du Québec]].<ref name="Lemay">{{cite news|last1=Lemay|first1=Daniel|title=Ordre des arts et lettres du Québec: Liza Frulla sera honorée|url=http://www.lapresse.ca/arts/nouvelles/201503/20/01-4853949-ordre-des-arts-et-lettres-du-quebec-liza-frulla-sera-honoree.php|accessdate=3 November 2016|work=La Presse|date=20 March 2015|language=fr-CA}}</ref>
Obomsawin was named an Honorary Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Canada]] for 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=RSC at the Movies|url=https://rsc-src.ca/en/events/annual-general-meeting-2013/networking-events/rsc-at-movies|website=[[Royal Society of Canada]]}}</ref> In January of that year, the [[Academy of Canadian Cinema & Television]] announced that Obomsawin would receive its Humanitarian Award for Exceptional Contributions to Community & Public Service, presented at the [[2nd Canadian Screen Awards]].<ref name="Walker2">{{cite news|last1=Walker|first1=Connie|title=Canadian Screen Awards recognize Aboriginal talent|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/aboriginal/canadian-screen-awards-recognize-aboriginal-talent-1.2494969|accessdate=7 September 2016|work=CBC News|date=13 January 2014}}</ref> At the [[2013 Toronto International Film Festival]], she was a recipient of a Birks Diamond Tribute to the Year's Women in Film.<ref name="O'Connell">{{cite news|last1=O'Connell|first1=Sandra|title=TIFF13: Appreciating Canadian women in film|url=https://theprovince.com/entertainment/tiff13-appreciating-canadian-women-in-film|accessdate=7 September 2016|work=Vancouver Province|issue=16 September 2013|publisher=Postmedia Network Inc.}}</ref>
In 2010, she was named to the [[Playback (magazine)|Playback]] Canadian Film & Television Hall of Fame.<ref name="Playback HofF"/> In the spring of 2009, Obomsawin was honoured with a special retrospective at [[Hot Docs]] and received the festival's Hot Docs Outstanding Achievement Award.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Alanis Obamsawin at Toronto's Hot Docs Festival |url=http://www.cbc.ca/aboriginal/2009/04/alanis_obamsawin_at_torontos_h/ |date=2009-04-15 |accessdate=2015-10-26 |website=CBC Aboriginal |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100810171532/http://www.cbc.ca/aboriginal/2009/04/alanis_obamsawin_at_torontos_h/ |archivedate=August 10, 2010 }}</ref> A retrospective her work was also held from May 14 to 26, 2008 at the [[Museum of Modern Art]] in New York City.<ref name="MOMA">{{cite news|url=http://press.moma.org/images/press/film_archive/AlanisObomsawin_RELandSCH.FINAL.pdf |title=MoMA PRESENTS MAJOR EXHIBITION OF THE FILMS OF CANADIAN FILMMAKER ALANIS OBOMSAWIN |date=April 18, 2008 |work=News release |publisher=Museum of Modern Art |accessdate=May 20, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100708073614/http://press.moma.org/images/press/film_archive/AlanisObomsawin_RELandSCH.FINAL.pdf |archivedate=July 8, 2010 |df=mdy }}</ref> That same month, she was honoured with the [[Governor General's Performing Arts Award]] for Lifetime Artistic Achievement, Canada's highest honour in the performing arts, at [[Rideau Hall]] in Ottawa.<ref>{{cite web|title=Alanis Obomsawin biography|url=http://ggpaa.ca/award-recipients/2008/obomsawin-alanis.aspx|publisher=Governor General's Performing Arts Awards Foundation|accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="CBC">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/arts/film/story/2009/03/24/hot-docs-lineup-program.html|title=Hot Docs film fest boasts strongest lineup ever after record submissions|date=March 24, 2009|work=CBC News|accessdate=April 16, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090327100453/http://www.cbc.ca/arts/film/story/2009/03/24/hot-docs-lineup-program.html| archivedate= March 27, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://ggpaa.ca/en/Awards_Press_Release_2008.pdf |title=GOVERNOR GENERAL'S PERFORMING ARTS AWARDS |date=March 12, 2008 |work=News release |publisher=Rideau Hall |accessdate=May 20, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181828/http://ggpaa.ca/en/Awards_Press_Release_2008.pdf |archivedate=July 6, 2011 }}</ref>
In March 2001, Obomsawin received a [[Governor General's Awards in Visual and Media Arts|Governor General's Award in Visual and Media Arts]].<ref name=GG2001>{{cite web|title=2001 Winners |url=http://ggavma.canadacouncil.ca/archive/2001/winners |website=Governor General's Awards in Visual and Media Arts |accessdate=25 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402091900/http://ggavma.canadacouncil.ca/archive/2001/winners |archivedate=April 2, 2015 }}</ref> An [[Officer of the Order of Canada]], Obomsawin's many honours also include the Luminaria Tribute for Lifetime Achievement from the [[Santa Fe Film Festival]], International Documentary Association's Pioneer Award,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117913183.html?categoryid=1236&cs=1&query=%22Alanis+Obomsawin%22|title=Org to fete doc pioneer|last=McNary|first=Dave|date=November 7, 2004|work=Variety|publisher=Reed Elsevier Inc.|accessdate=May 20, 2009}}</ref> the Toronto Women in Film and Television's (TWIFT) Outstanding Achievement Award in Direction, the Canadian Native Arts Foundation National Aboriginal Achievement Award, and the Outstanding Contributions Award from the Canadian Sociology and Anthropology Association (CSAA). The latter marks the first time that the CSAA has honoured someone who is not an academic in the field of sociology and anthropology.
Obomsawin also received a fellowship from the [[Ontario College of Art]], an Honorary Doctor of Letters from [[York University]], an Honorary Doctor of Laws from [[Concordia University]], an Honorary Doctor of Literature from [[Carleton University]], an Honorary Doctor of Laws from the [[University of Western Ontario]] (October 2007), Honorary Doctor of Letters from the [[University of British Columbia]] (May 2010),<ref>{{cite web|title=Dr. Alanis Obomsawin, O.C.|url=http://graduation.ubc.ca/event/honorary-degrees/2010-honorary-degree-recipients/alanis-obomsawin/|website=2010 Honorary Degree Recipients|publisher=University of British Columbia|accessdate=7 September 2016}}</ref> Honorary Doctor of Laws from [[Dalhousie University]] (April 2016),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dal.ca/academics/convocation/ceremonies/honorary_degree_recipients/hon_degree_2016/alanis_obomsawin.html|title=ALANIS OBOMSAWIN, O.C.|last=|first=|date=|website=Dalhousie University Convocation|publisher=Dalhousie University|access-date=7 September 2016}}</ref> as well as an Honorary Doctor of Laws (June 2018).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ryerson.ca/news-events/news/2018/06/meet-the-honorary-doctorates-of-spring-convocation/|title=Meet the honorary doctorates of spring convocation|website=Ryerson University|language=en|access-date=2018-08-22}}</ref> She has taught at the Summer Institute of Film and Television in Ottawa.
Obomsawin has chaired the Board of Directors of the Native Women's Shelter of Montreal and sat on the [[Canada Council]]'s First People's Advisory Board. She was also a board member of Studio 1, the NFB's Aboriginal studio, and a former advisor to the New Initiatives in Film, a [[Studio D]] program for women of colour and women of the First Nations. As a member of the board of [[Aboriginal Voices]], she was part of an initiative to obtain a radio licence for the organization. A lifetime member of the board of directors for the [[Aboriginal Peoples Television Network]], Obomsawin is also a member of the board for [[Vermont Public Television]] and [[National Geographic Channel|National Geographic]] International.
The impact of Obomsawin's career on documentary and Indigenous film has been highlighted by the creation of two awards in her name. [[Cinema Politica]] has awarded the "Alanis Obomsawin Award for Commitment to Community and Resistance" since 2011 and "was inspired by Ms. Obomsawin's awe-inspiring and unstoppable dedication to social justice and political documentary."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cinemapolitica.org/blog/network/alanis-obomsawin-award-extended-call-nominations|title=Alanis Obomsawin Award|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> [[ImagineNATIVE Film + Media Arts Festival]] presents "The Alanis Obomsawin Best Documentary Award" every year for achievement in documentary film .<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.imaginenative.org/2016-award-winners-2|title=imagineNative Alanis Obomsawin Best Documentary Award|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Partial filmography== * 1984 - ''[[Incident at Restigouche]]'' * 1986 - ''[[Richard Cardinal: Cry from a Diary of a Métis Child]]'' - Director/Writer * 1993 - ''[[Kanehsatake: 270 Years of Resistance]]'' - Director/Writer/Producer * 1995 - ''My Name is Kahentiiosta'' - Director/Writer/Producer * 1997 - ''Spudwrench – Kahnawake Man'' - Director/Writer/Producer * 2000 - ''[[Rocks at Whiskey Trench]]'' - Director/Writer/Producer * 2002 - ''Is the Crown At War With Us? - ''Director/Writer/Producer * 2003 - ''For John'' (dir. Dale Montour) - Producer * 2003 - ''Our Nationhood'' - Director/Writer/Producer * 2005 - ''Sigwan'' - Director/Writer/Producer * 2006 - ''Waban-Aki: People from Where the Sun Rises'' - Director/Writer/Producer * 2007 - ''[[Gene Boy Came Home]]'' - Director/Writer/Producer * 2012 - ''[[The People of the Kattawapiskak River]]'' - Director/Writer/Producer * 2013 - ''[[Hi-Ho Mistahey!]]'' - Director/Writer/Producer * 2014 - ''[[Trick or Treaty?]]'' - Director/Writer/Producer * 2016 - ''[[We Can't Make the Same Mistake Twice]]'' * 2017 - ''[[Our People Will Be Healed]]''

{{Infobox scientist |name = Alexander Alexandrovich Bolonkin |native_name = Александр Александрович Болонкин |native_name_lang = Russian |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1933|03|14}} |birth_place = [[Perm]], [[USSR]] |death_date = |death_place = |residence = |citizenship = * {{Flag|Soviet Union}} (1933–1987) * {{Flag|United States}} (1987–present) |nationality = [[Russians|Russian]] |ethnicity = |field = [[cybernetics|cybernetician]] |workplaces = * [[Moscow State Aviation Technological University|Moscow Aviation Technology Institute]] * [[Bauman Moscow State Technical University]] * [[New Jersey Institute of Technology]] * [[NASA]] * [[National Research Council (United States)|National Research Council]] |alma_mater = [[Perm Aviation College]], [[Kazan Aviation Institute]], [[Kiev State University]], [[Moscow Aviation Institute]], [[Leningrad Polytechnic University]] |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = human rights activism with participation in [[dissident movement in the Soviet Union]] |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = |spouse = |children = }}
'''Alexander Alexandrovich Bolonkin''' ({{lang-ru|Алекса́ндр Алекса́ндрович Боло́нкин}}, born 14 March 1933, [[Perm]]) is a Russian-American scientist and academic who worked in the Soviet aviation, space and rocket industries and lectured in Moscow universities, before being arrested in 1972 by the [[KGB]] as a [[dissident]]. He served terms of imprisonment and [[internal exile]] for 15 years until 1987, when he emigrated to the US as a political refugee.
He has since lectured at American universities and worked as a researcher at [[NASA]] and for the [[National Research Council (United States)|National Research Council]]. He is a member of the Board of Directors of the [[International Space Agency]], Chairman of the Space Flights section, member of the Advisory Board of the Lifeboat Foundation and its Space Settlement, and the founding President of the International Association of Former Soviet Political Prisoners and Victims of the Communist Regime (IASPPV).
== Life and career == Bolonkin was born in [[Perm]]. He earned a bachelor's degree in aviation engineering from [[Perm Aviation College]] in 1952, a master's degree in aircraft from [[Kazan Aviation Institute]] in 1958, a master's degree in mathematics from [[Kiev University]] in 1963, a doctorate in aerospace from the [[Moscow Aviation Institute]] in 1964, and a postdoctoral degree in [[cybernetics]] and mathematics from [[Leningrad Polytechnic University]] in 1971.
He worked at the [[Antonov]] aviation design company as a senior engineer and head of the aerodynamics group, participating in the design of aircraft from the [[An-8]] to the [[An-124]], and at the [[Valentin Glushko|Glushko]] rocketry company, participating in the design of rocket engines, and lectured at the Moscow Aviation Institute, the [[Moscow State Aviation Technological University|Moscow Aviation Technology Institute]], and the [[Bauman Moscow State Technical University]].<ref name=Morgulis>{{cite web|first=Mikhail |last=Morgulis |url=http://russianamericanbusiness.org/web_CURRENT/articles/352/1/Alexander-Bolonkin |title=Alexander Bolonkin |website=Russian-American Business |date=January 21, 2009 |accessdate=February 8, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150102154905/http://russianamericanbusiness.org/web_CURRENT/articles/352/1/Alexander-Bolonkin |archivedate=January 2, 2015 }}</ref>
In 1972 he was arrested by the KGB for intent to instigate [[democracy]] in the communist regime through dissemination of an underground newsletter,<ref name=glasgow>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2507&dat=19780816&id=HrdAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tKUMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2528,3212787 |agency=[[Reuters]] |title=Dissident gets five years in Siberia |newspaper=[[The Glasgow Herald]] |date=August 16, 1978 |page=2 }}</ref> listening to the [[Voice of America]] and reading and disseminating works by [[Andrei Sakharov]] and [[Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn]]. Bolonkin was sentenced to 4 years in a labour camp and 2 years in exile in [[Buryatia]].<ref name=glasgow/> Shortly before his sentence of exile ended Bolonkin was given a sentence of 2 years in a labour camp on a charge of stealing state property.<ref name=glasgow/> For 15 years he was tortured, imprisoned, and exiled in [[Nizhny Novgorod|Siberia]].<ref name=Morgulis/> In 1981 Sakharov appealed for international support to have him freed.<ref>{{cite news |agency=[[Associated Press]] |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2209&dat=19810505&id=SKkrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IP0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=6991,1034560 |title=Foreign Briefs |newspaper=[[Nashua Telegraph]] |date=May 5, 1981 |page=6 }}</ref> In April 1982 he made a televised recantation<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19820408&id=gU5PAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qQIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4812,5299534 |title=Imprisoned Soviet Activist Renounces Dissident Views |newspaper=[[Toledo Blade]] |date=April 8, 1982 |page=13 |agency=Reuters}}</ref> that [[Amnesty International]] ascribed to threats of beatings and rape.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ukrweekly.com/archive/1983/The_Ukrainian_Weekly_1983-11.pdf |title=Soviet dissident said to recant |newspaper=The Ukrainian Weekly |date=March 13, 1983 |page=2 |format=pdf }}</ref>
In 1987, during the early ''[[perestroika]]'', he was released and gained entry to the USA as a political refugee. In the USA he has lectured at [[New Jersey Institute of Technology]] and worked at NASA as a senior researcher and in the scientific laboratories of the [[US Air Force]] as a senior research fellow of the [[National Research Council (United States)|National Research Council]].<ref name=Carnegie>{{cite web|url=http://greatimmigrants.carnegie.org/profile/dr-alexander-bolonkin/ |title=Dr. Alexander Bolonkin |publisher=Carnegie Corporation of New York |date=2014 |website=Great Immigrants |accessdate=February 8, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150208170713/http://greatimmigrants.carnegie.org/profile/dr-alexander-bolonkin/ |archivedate=February 8, 2015 }}</ref> He subsequently worked in Israel as chief scientist at the Strategic Solutions Technology Group.<ref name=Today>{{cite news |first=David |last=Lev |url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/143130#.VNeXnS6-Rpk |title=Space-Age Domes Could Protect Cities from Missiles - and Fallout |newspaper=[[Israel Today]] |date=March 24, 2011 }}</ref>
==Research== {{As of|2009}} Bolonkin held 17 patents. Among his innovations in space exploration are a [[Space elevator|cable space launcher]], a [[hypersonic tube launcher]], a kinetic anti-gravitation system, a [[multi-reflex propulsion device]], space towers, an electrostatic [[space sail]], an electric [[ramjet]] space propulsion device, and the [[cable aviation]] device.<ref name=Morgulis/> In an ''[[Izvestia]]'' interview in 1998, he predicted the achievement of [[cybernetic immortality]] by 2020,<ref>{{cite web |first=D. I. |last=Dubrovsky |url=http://hplusmagazine.com/2013/01/21/d-i-dubrovsky-cybernetic-immortality-fantasy-or-scientific-problem/ |title=Cybernetic immortality. Fantasy or scientific problem? |newspaper=h+ |date=January 21, 2013 }}</ref> and in 2011 he was consulted as an expert by the [[2045 Initiative]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://2045.com/expert/12.html |title=Experts: Professor Aleksandr A. Bolonkin. E-beings: From a Sick Head to an Artificial Body |publisher=[[2045 Initiative]] |date=May 13, 2011 }}</ref> He also developed the idea of domed cities as a protection against [[fallout]],<ref name=Today/><ref>{{cite web |first=Shmuel |last=Neumann |url=http://israelbehindthenews.com/technology-from-israel-can-make-tokyo-safe-from-fallout-in-3-weeks/7064/ |title=Technology from Israel can make Tokyo safe from fallout in 3 weeks: Making Cities Impervious to Nuclear Fallout |website=Israel Behind the News |date=March 17, 2011 }}</ref> and in physics researched the production of what he called "AB-Matter" through [[femtotechnology]].<ref name=Today/>
==Board memberships and foundations== Bolonkin is a member of the Board of Directors of the [[International Space Agency]] and chairman of the space flights section.<ref name=Morgulis/><ref>{{cite web |title=Active International Space Agency Programs |url=https://internationalspaceagency.weebly.com/isa-programs.html}}</ref>
He is also a member of the advisory board of the [[Lifeboat Foundation]] and its space settlement board,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lifeboat.com/ex/bios.alexander.bolonkin |title=Advisory Board: Alexander Bolonkin |publisher=The Lifeboat Foundation |accessdate=February 8, 2015}}</ref> and the founding President of the International Association of Former Soviet Political Prisoners and Victims of the Communist Regime (IASPPV) and co-founder and co-chair of ARA, an organization for the civil and human rights of [[Russian-American]]s.<ref name=Morgulis/><ref name=Carnegie/>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{For|the award winning American actress|Anne Bancroft}} {{Infobox person | name = Ann Bancroft | image = AnnBancroft2006-02-06.JPG | alt = | caption = Ann Bancroft in 2006, holding a journal she kept on a trip to the Arctic | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1955|9|29}} | birth_place = [[Mendota Heights, Minnesota]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma mater = [[University of Oregon]] | residence = [[Scandia, Minnesota]] | other_names = | known_for = First woman to trek to the [[North Pole]] | occupation = Explorer, teacher, author, public speaker }}
'''Ann Bancroft''' (born September 29, 1955) is an [[United States|American]] author, teacher, adventurer, and public speaker. She was the first woman to successfully finish a number of arduous expeditions to the [[Arctic]] and [[Antarctic]]. She was inducted into the [[National Women's Hall of Fame]] in 1995.<ref>{{cite web|author=Women of the Hall |url=http://www.greatwomen.org/women-of-the-hall/search-the-hall/details/2/15-Bancroft |title=Ann Bancroft - National Women's Hall of Fame |publisher=Greatwomen.org |date= |accessdate=2015-01-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004091111/http://www.greatwomen.org/women-of-the-hall/search-the-hall/details/2/15-Bancroft |archivedate=October 4, 2013 }}</ref>
==Biography== Ann Bancroft was born in Mendota Heights, Minnesota,<ref name=":0" /> and grew up in [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|St. Paul, Minnesota]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Explorer Ann Bancroft Plays 'Not My Job'|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=128116886|newspaper=NPR|date=June 26, 2010}}</ref> Bancroft spent two years in Kenya in her fifth and sixth grades.<ref name=":0" /> Bancroft began leading wilderness expeditions when she was 8-years-old when she convinced her cousins to join her on backyard expeditions.<ref name=":0" /> She described her family as one of risk takers. Bancroft struggled with [[dyslexia]] from an early age, but she nevertheless graduated High School and was accepted at the University of Oregon where she graduated with a Physical Education Degree in 1981.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://dyslexia.yale.edu/story/ann-bancroft/|title=Ann Bancroft, Polar Explorer - Yale Dyslexia|work=Yale Dyslexia|access-date=2018-05-16|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="around.uoregon.edu">{{Cite news|url=https://around.uoregon.edu/ann-bancroft|title=Ann Bancroft|date=2017-03-09|work=Around the O|access-date=2018-05-16|language=en}}</ref> Bancroft was a camper and staff member at YMCA [[Camp Widjiwagan]] in Ely, MN.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ymcamn.org/camps/camp_widjiwagan|title=Camp Widjiwagan|website=YMCA Twin Cities|language=en|access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref> Bancroft also taught Physical Education and Special Education in St. Paul and Minneapolis, Minnesota.<ref name=":0" /> Bancroft became a wilderness instructor and a gym teacher in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota|Minneapolis]] (at Clara Barton Open School) and [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|St. Paul]].
Ann Bancroft founded the Ann Bancroft Foundation in 1991.<ref name=":0" /> The Ann Bancroft foundation supports the Wilderness Inquiry group and Bancroft currently teaches at Wilderness Inquiry.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.annbancroftfoundation.org/about-us/about-abf/|title=Ann Bancroft Foundation :: About Ann|website=www.annbancroftfoundation.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref><ref name=":1" /> The Wilderness Inquiry group allows individuals and families to go on outdoor adventures, and the adventures are open to people of all ability levels. Bancroft currently co-owns an exploration company, [http://www.yourexpedition.com Bancroft Arnesen Explore], with [[Liv Arnesen]]. Bancroft has been on expeditions on the Ganges River in India, crossed Greenland, traveled to the North Pole, and crossed the South Pole.
==Expeditions== Bancroft gave up her physical education and special education teaching posts in 1986 in order to participate with the "[[Will Steger]] International North Pole Expedition". She arrived at the [[North Pole]] together with five other team members after 56 days using [[dogsled]]s.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.minnpost.com/community-voices/2011/05/remembering-north-pole-trek-1986-and-looking-forward-anniversary-celebratio|title=Remembering the North Pole trek of 1986 -- and looking forward to the anniversary celebration|work=MinnPost|access-date=2018-05-16|language=en}}</ref> This made Bancroft the first woman to reach the [[North Pole]] on foot and by sled.
She was also the first woman to cross both polar ice caps to reach the North and South Poles, as well as the first woman to ski across Greenland.<ref name="bare_url">{{cite web|url=http://klobuchar.senate.gov/newsreleases_detail.cfm?id=278587& |title=Senator Amy Klobuchar |publisher=Klobuchar.senate.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-07-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120327164606/http://klobuchar.senate.gov/newsreleases_detail.cfm?id=278587& |archivedate=2012-03-27 }}</ref> In 1992-1993, Bancroft led a four-woman expedition to the [[South Pole]] on skis; this expedition was the first all-female expedition to cross the ice to the South Pole.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://keynotespeakers.com/speaker_detail.php?speakerid=3214 |title=Ann Bancroft - Speaker Profile |publisher=Keynotespeakers.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-21}}</ref>
In 2001, Ann and Norwegian adventurer [[Liv Arnesen]] became the first women to ski across Antarctica.<ref name="bare_url"/>
In March 2007, Bancroft and [[Liv Arnesen]] took part in a trek across the Arctic Ocean to draw attention to the problem of global warming. The two explorers were followed be millions of school children.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.educationworld.com/a_curr/curr322.shtml|title=The Bancroft Arnesen Expedition: Two Teachers Take to the Ice to Expand Classroom Walls {{!}} Education World|website=www.educationworld.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref> However, according to ''[[The Washington Post]]'', the expedition was called off "after [[Liv Arnesen]] suffered frostbite in three of her toes, and extreme cold temperatures drained the batteries in some of their electronic equipment."<ref name="washpost">{{citation |title=Frostbite Ends Bancroft-Arnesen Trek |first=Patrick |last=Condon |periodical=[[The Washington Post]] |date=2007-03-12 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/03/12/AR2007031200997.html |accessdate=2007-09-04}}</ref>
In 2017, Bancroft led an expedition on the Ganges River as part of the "Access Water Initiative Series." <ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.splendidtable.org/story/ann-bancrofts-latest-adventure-finding-and-preserving-fresh-water|title=Ann Bancroft's latest adventure: Finding, and preserving, fresh water|last=|first=|date=|work=Splendid Table|access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref> The Ganges River expedition's purpose was to raise awareness of the importance of clean water and that waste will travel downstream.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://offthebeatenpagetravel.com/2015/11/06/why-is-polar-explorer-ann-bancroft-paddling-the-ganges/|title=Why is Polar Explorer Ann Bancroft Paddling the Ganges?|date=2015-11-06|work=Off The Beaten Page Travel|access-date=2018-05-16|language=en-US}}</ref> This expedition was a 60-day trip on 1,500 miles of waterway.<ref name=":2" />
Bancroft plans to boat down the Mississippi river in 2018 with Arnesen and other female explorers.<ref name="dl-online.com">{{Cite news|url=http://www.dl-online.com/news/4403732-ends-earth-and-back-minnesota-native-ann-bancroft-has-visited-both-north-south-poles|title=To the ends of the earth and back: Minnesota native Ann Bancroft...|last=|first=|date=|work=DL-online|access-date=2018-05-16|language=en}}</ref> Future expeditions will be conducted on every continent. This initiative aims to encourage children to protect their waterways, which is a vital resource.<ref name=":2" /> In 2018, Bancroft will paddle down the 2,320 mile Mississippi River.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wildernessinquiry.org/current-news/news-notes/join-explorer-ann-bancroft-great-river-race/|title=Join Explorer Ann Bancroft in the Great River Race - Wilderness Inquiry|work=Wilderness Inquiry|access-date=2018-05-16|language=en-US}}</ref> Future trips include Africa in 2019, Oceania in 2021, South America in 2023, Europe in 2025, and Antarctica in 2027.<ref name=":1" />
==Activist== Bancroft is openly [[Homosexual|gay]]<ref name="histories">{{citation |title=Lesbian histories and cultures |work=Encyclopedia of lesbian and gay histories and cultures |first=Bonnie |last=Zimmerman |volume=1 |publisher=Taylor & Francis |year=2000 |isbn=0-8153-1920-7|page=253|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nvt8el4QtPwC&pg=PA253 }}</ref> and in 2006, she publicly campaigned against a proposed amendment to the [[Minnesota Constitution]] to prohibit any legal recognition of marriages or civil unions between members of the same sex.<ref name="advocate">{{citation |url=http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/2004/03/25_mccalluml_samesexredux/ |title=Opponents rally against gay marriage ban |first=Laura |last=McCallum |work=Minnesota Public Radio |date=25 March 2004 |accessdate=24 December 2010}}</ref>
Bancroft also supports awareness of Access Water, Winter Warm-Up challenges, and [[Global Warming]] <ref name="dl-online.com"/><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://stillwaterschools.org/district/district-news-e-news/polar-explorer-ann-bancroft-sleds-marine-elementary-school|title=Polar explorer Ann Bancroft sleds by Marine Elementary School|work=Stillwater Area Public Schools - Minnesota|access-date=2018-05-16|language=en}}</ref><ref name="washingtonpost.com">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/03/12/AR2007031200997.html|title=Frostbite Ends Bancroft-Arnesen Trek|last=CONDON|first=PATRICK|date=2007-03-12|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-05-16|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
==Select achievements==
* First woman to reach the [[North Pole]] in 1986.<ref name="around.uoregon.edu" /> * Named Woman of the Year by [[Ms. Magazine]] in 1987.<ref name="around.uoregon.edu" /> * Leader of the first east-west crossing of [[Greenland]] in 1992.<ref name="around.uoregon.edu" /> * Became the first woman to reach both poles in 1992.<ref name="around.uoregon.edu" /><ref name="dl-online.com" /> * Leader of the first all-female expedition to the [[South Pole]] in 1992-1993.<ref name="around.uoregon.edu" /> * Included in Remarkable Women of the Twentieth Century in 1998.<ref name="around.uoregon.edu" /> * One of the first two women to cross Antarctica on foot with [[Liv Arnesen]] in 2001. * Named Woman of the Year by [[Glamour Magazine]] in 2001.<ref name="around.uoregon.edu" /> * Induction into the [[National Women's Hall of Fame]] for the United States in 2005.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.womenofthehall.org/inductee/ann-bancroft/|title=Bancroft, Ann - National Women’s Hall of Fame|work=National Women’s Hall of Fame|access-date=2018-05-16|language=en-US}}</ref> * Attempted another expedition to the North Pole with [[Liv Arnesen]], but in 2007, [[frostbite]] stopped their trek in 2007 <ref name="washingtonpost.com" /> * Named one of history's greatest polar explorers in 2011.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mnn.com/earth-matters/animals/photos/13-of-historys-greatest-polar-explorers/ann-bancroft|title=13 of history's greatest polar explorers|work=MNN - Mother Nature Network|access-date=2018-05-16|language=en}}</ref> * Finished the first Source to Sea Access Water expedition on the Ganges River with seven other women in 2015, covering 1,500 miles in 60 days.<ref name="dl-online.com" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://bancroftarnesen.eco/?page_id=1038|title=Home|website=Bancroft Arnesen Explore|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref>
==Books==
* Bancroft, Ann & Nancy Loewen. (2001) Four to the Pole! The American Women's Expedition to Antarctica, 1992-1993. Linnet Books. * Arnesen, Liz & Ann Bancroft with Cheryl Dahle. (2003) No Horizon Is So Far: Two Women and Their Extraordinary Journey Across Antarctica. De Capo Press. {{ISBN|0-7382-0794-2}}.<ref name="trove.nla.gov.au">{{Cite book|url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/version/36983047|title=No horizon is so far : two women and their extraordinary journey across Antarctica|last=Arnesen|first=Liv|last2=Bancroft|first2=Ann|last3=Dahle|first3=Cheryl|date=2003|publisher=[Cambridge, MA] : Da Capo Press|isbn=0738207942|language=English}}</ref> * No Horizon Is So Far describes Ann Bancroft's and Lis Arnesen's 1,700 mile trek across Antarctica in 2000-2001.<ref name="trove.nla.gov.au" /> The nonfiction book won an Amelia Bloomer award in 2005.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ameliabloomer.wordpress.com/2005-amelia-bloomer-list/|title=2005 Amelia Bloomer List|date=2009-02-04|work=Amelia Bloomer Project|access-date=2018-05-16|language=en-US}}</ref> * Bancroft, Ann & Liz Arnesen. (2003). Ann and Liz Cross Antarctica. De Capo Press. {{ISBN|0-7382-0934-1}}.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=128116886 Explorer Ann Bancroft Plays 'Not My Job' - NPR Wait Wait Don't Tell Me, June 26, 2010]
{{National Women's Hall of Fame}}
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=October 2009}} {{Infobox astronaut | name = Brent W. Jett Jr. | other_names = Brent Ward Jett Jr. | image = Brent Jett.jpg | type = [[NASA]] astronaut | status = Retired | nationality = American | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1958|10|5}} | death_date = | birth_place = [[Pontiac, Michigan]], U.S. | death_place = | occupation = [[Naval aviator]], [[test pilot]] | alma_mater = [[United States Naval Academy|USNA]], B.S. 1981
[[Naval Postgraduate School|NPS]], M.S. 1989 | rank = [[Captain (naval)|Captain]], [[United States Navy|USN]] | selection = [[List of astronauts by selection#1992|1992 NASA Group 14]] | space_time = 41d 18h 01m | missions = [[STS-72]], [[STS-81]], [[STS-97]], [[STS-115]] | insignia = [[File:Sts-72-patch.png|40px]] [[File:Sts-81-patch.png|40px]] [[File:Sts-97-patch.svg|40px]] [[File:STS-115 patch.png|40px]] | retirement = January 2013 | awards = [[File:Dfc-usa.jpg|20px|alt=Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|link=Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)]] }} '''Brent Ward Jett Jr.''' (born October 5, 1958), ([[Captain (United States)|Capt]], [[United States Navy|USN]], Ret.), is a retired American [[United States Navy|naval officer]] and [[United States naval aviator|aviator]], [[test pilot]], [[aerospace engineering|aerospace]] and [[aeronautical engineer]], and [[NASA]] [[astronaut]]. ==Personal data== Jett was born in [[Pontiac, Michigan]], but considers [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida]], to be his hometown. Married to Janet Leigh Lyon of [[Patuxent River, Maryland]]. His hobbies are [[Water skiing|water]] and [[snow skiing]], [[board sailing]], [[boating]], [[running]], [[basketball]], and [[Squash (sport)|squash]].[http://www.spacefacts.de/bios/astronauts/english/jett_brent.htm Brent W. Jett's personal data and recreational interests] ==Education== He received a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in [[Aerospace Engineering]] from the [[United States Naval Academy]] in 1981. He received a [[Master of Science]] degree in [[Aeronautical Engineering]] from the U.S. [[Naval Postgraduate School]] in 1989.[http://www.usna.edu/NotableGraduates/astronauts/1981jett.php Brent W. Jett's education] ==Naval service== Jett was designated a [[Naval Aviator]] in March 1983, and reported to [[VF-101]] at [[Naval Air Station Oceana]], [[Virginia]] for initial [[F-14 Tomcat]] training. Upon completion of this training, he was assigned to [[VF-74]] and made overseas deployments to the [[Mediterranean Sea]] and [[Indian Ocean]] aboard the [[aircraft carrier]] {{USS|Saratoga|CV-60|6}}. While assigned to VF-74, he was designated as an airwing qualified [[Landing signal officer|Landing Signal Officer]] (LSO) and also attended the [[Navy Fighter Weapons School]] ([[TOPGUN]]).[http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/jett.html Jett's flight experience and naval service] Jett was selected for the U.S. Naval Postgraduate School – Test Pilot School Cooperative Education Program in July 1986, and completed 15 months of graduate work at [[Monterey, California]], before attending the [[U.S. Naval Test Pilot School]] in June 1989. After graduation in June 1990, he worked as a project [[test pilot]] at the Carrier Stability Department of the Strike Aircraft Test Directorate, [[Naval Air Test Center]], flying the [[F-14A]]/[[F-14B|B]]/[[F-14D|D]], [[T-45A]], and [[A-7E]]. Jett returned to the operational Navy in September 1991 and was again assigned to VF-74, flying the F-14B aboard USS ''Saratoga''. He has logged over 5,000 flight hours in more than 30 different aircraft and has over 450 carrier landings. ==NASA career== Selected by NASA in March 1992, Jett reported to the [[Johnson Space Center]] in August 1992. After two years of various technical assignments in the Astronaut Office, Jett was assigned to his first mission as the pilot of [[STS-72]]. A year later he again served as Pilot on [[STS-81]]. From June 1997 to February 1998, he served as NASA Director of Operations at the [[Yuri Gagarin Cosmonaut Training Center]], [[Star City, Russia]]. Two years later he was the Commander on [[STS-97]]. Finally, he served as the Commander of [[Space Shuttle Atlantis|Space Shuttle ''Atlantis'']] on [[STS-115]]. A veteran of four space missions, he has traveled over 12.1 million miles, and logged a total of 41 days, 18 hours, and 1 minute in space. Jett retired from the U.S. Navy in July 2007, but remained with NASA. In November 2007, he was appointed as Director of Flight Crew Operations. From November 2007 to February 2011, he was Director of Flight Crew Operations at JSC. From March 2010 to January 2013, Jett was the Deputy Manager for the NASA Commercial Crew Program. He retired from NASA in January 2013. ===Spaceflight experience=== [[STS-72]]: [[Space Shuttle Endeavour|''Endeavour'']] (January 11–20, 1996) was a 9-day flight during which the crew retrieved the Space Flyer Unit (launched from Japan 10-months earlier), deployed and retrieved the OAST-Flyer, and conducted two spacewalks to demonstrate and evaluate techniques to be used in the assembly of the [[International Space Station]]. [[STS-81]]: [[Space Shuttle Atlantis|''Atlantis'']] (January 12–22, 1997) was the fifth in a series of joint missions between the U.S. [[Space Shuttle]] and the Russian Space Station [[Mir]] and the second one involving an exchange of U.S. astronauts. In five days of docked operations more than three tons of food, water, experiment equipment and samples were moved back and forth between the two spacecraft. [[STS-97]]: ''Endeavour'' (November 30 to December 11, 2000) was the fifth American mission to build and enhance the capabilities of the International Space Station. STS-97 delivered the first set of U.S.-provided solar arrays and batteries as well as radiators to provide cooling. Three [[spacewalk]]s were conducted to complete assembly operations while the arrays were attached and unfurled. A communications system for voice and telemetry was also installed. [[STS-115]]: ''Atlantis'' (September 9–21, 2006) was the first assembly mission to the International Space Station after the [[Space Shuttle Columbia disaster|''Columbia'' disaster]]. STS-115 delivered a new truss segment, including [[solar panels]], to the station.[http://www.astronautix.com/astros/jett.htm Brent W. Jett's NASA and space flight experiences] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020127042959/http://www.astronautix.com/astros/jett.htm |date=2002-01-27 }} ==Organizations== * [[Society of Experimental Test Pilots]] * [[Association of Naval Aviation]] * U.S. Naval Academy Alumni Association * [[Association of Space Explorers]] ==Special honors== * Graduated first of 976 in the Class of 1981 at U.S. Naval Academy * Distinguished Graduate U.S. Naval Test Pilot School Class 95 * Awarded the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] * Awarded the [[Defense Meritorious Service Medal]] and [[Defense Superior Service Medal]]s * Awarded the [[Navy Commendation Medal]] * Awarded the [[NASA Exceptional Service Medal]] * Awarded 3 [[NASA Space Flight Medal]]s * Awarded the various other service awards * A portion of Northeast 56th Street in Jett's home city of Fort Lauderdale, Florida, has been designated "Brent Jett Boulevard" in his honor. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Brent W. Jett, Jr.}} {{Portal|Biography|United States Navy|Spaceflight}} * [http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/jett.html Jett's official NASA biography] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20020127042959/http://www.astronautix.com/astros/jett.htm Astronautix biography of Brent W. Jett Jr.] * [http://www.spacefacts.de/bios/astronauts/english/jett_brent.htm Spacefacts biography of Brent W. Jett Jr.] * [http://www.spaceacts.com/STARSHIP/seh/jett.html Jett at Spaceacts] {{NASA Astronaut Group 14}} {{US Navy navbox}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jett, Brent W. Jr.}} [[Category:1958 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1996 in spaceflight]] [[Category:1997 in spaceflight]] [[Category:2000 in spaceflight]] [[Category:2006 in spaceflight]] [[Category:American astronauts]] [[Category:American aerospace engineers]] [[Category:United States Navy astronauts]] [[Category:NASA people]] [[Category:People from Pontiac, Michigan]] [[Category:People from Fort Lauderdale, Florida]] [[Category:United States Naval Academy alumni]] [[Category:United States Naval Test Pilot School alumni]] [[Category:Naval Postgraduate School alumni]] [[Category:Aviators from Michigan]] [[Category:United States Navy officers]] [[Category:United States Naval Aviators]] [[Category:American test pilots]] [[Category:Recipients of the Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)]] [[Category:Recipients of the Defense Superior Service Medal]] [[Category:Recipients of the NASA Exceptional Service Medal]]

{{Infobox person | name = Bucek Depp | image = Bucek Depp, Qubicle, 01.09.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date|1973|1|29|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Daerah Khusus Ibukota Jakarta|Jakarta]], [[Indonesia]] | birthname = Al Aththur Muchtar | othername = Bucek | death_date = | yearsactive = 1991-present | nationality = [[Indonesia]]n | occupation = Actor, model | spouse = [[Titi DJ]] (m. 1995{{ndash}}97, divorced) [[Unique Priscilla]] (m. 2001{{ndash}}07, divorced) | partner = | children = 4 | relatives = [[Al Fathir Muchtar]] (brother)
[[Fera Feriska]] (sister-in-law) | parents = Yus Machfud Muchtar (father)
Eleonora Muchtar (mother) | genre = | alma_mater = [[:id:SMA Negeri 6 Jakarta|SMA Negeri 6 Jakarta]] | influences = | influenced = | website = }} '''Bucek Depp''' a.k.a. '''Bucek''' (born '''Al Aththur Muchtar''', January 29, 1973, [[Jakarta]]) is an Indonesian model and actor. ==Career== His father Yus Mahfud Muchtar, is a [[Betawi people|betawi]], of [[Arab Indonesians|Arab]] descent and his mother Eleonora is [[Dutch people|Dutch]].{{cite web | url = http://celebrity.okezone.com/read/2008/10/17/33/155084/digosipkan-ditangkap-bucek-depp-ngaku-di-bali |title=Digosipkan Ditangkap, Bucek Depp Ngaku di Bali | date = October 17, 2008}} His real name is Al Arthur Muchtar, his moniker '''Bucek Depp''' would attribute to him the end of his teens, when he start his modeling career.{{cite web | url = http://celebrity.okezone.com/read/2014/04/15/33/970519/bucek-depp-akui-pernah-kumpul-kebo-di-usia-20-tahun |title=Bucek Depp Akui Pernah Kumpul "Kebo" di Usia 20 Tahun | date = April 15, 2014}} It is the big brother of the Indonesian actor [[Al Fathir Muchtar]] who was also a model in her youth, and the brother-in-law of the actress [[Fera Feriska]] since 2006.{{cite web | url = http://www.kapanlagi.com/foto/berita-foto/indonesia/00856fathir_muchtar-20060513-003-wawan.html |title=FATHIR MUCHTAR-FERA FERISKA | date = May 13, 2006}} ==Filmography== * ''Sekretaris'' (1991) * ''Pengantin Remaja'' (1991) * ''Kuldesak'' (1998) * ''Beth'' (2002) * ''[[Brownies (film)|Brownies]]'' (2005) * ''[[Mereka Bilang, Saya Monyet!]]'' (2008) * ''Operation Wedding'' (2013) * ''Cinta Brontosaurus'' (2013) * ''Merry Go Round'' (2013) * ''Manusia Setengah Salmon'' (2013) * ''7 Misi Rahasia Sophie'' (2014) * ''Me & You vs The World'' (2014) * ''Marmut Merah Jambu'' (2014) * ''Air & Api'' (2015) * [[Tiger Boy]] (2015) == Soap Opera == * ''Nadin'' (2017) as Chanda ==Video Clips== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Artist |- | 1995 | Bintang-Bintang | [[Titi DJ]] |- |} == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|1237533|Bucek Depp}} * {{id}} [http://www.kapanlagi.com/indonesia/b/bucek_depp/ Profil Bucek Depp] Kapanlagi.com * [http://instagram.com/bucek Instagram Bucek Depp] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Depp, Bucek}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1973 births]] [[Category:Indonesian male models]] [[Category:Indonesian actors]] [[Category:21st-century Indonesian male actors]] [[Category:Indonesian male television actors]] [[Category:Indonesian male actors]] [[Category:Male actors from Jakarta]] [[Category:Indonesian Muslims]] [[Category:Indo people]] [[Category:Betawi people]] [[Category:Indonesian people of Dutch descent]] [[Category:Indonesian people of Yemeni descent]] [[Category:Indonesian people stubs]]

[[Surgeon Rear-Admiral]] '''Charles Marsh Beadnell''' (17 February 1872 – 27 September 1947), best known as '''C. Marsh Beadnell''', was a British surgeon and [[Royal Navy]] officer.<ref name="Nature">Anonymous. (1947). [http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v160/n4070/abs/160598a0.html "Surgeon Rear-Admiral C. M. Beadnell, C.B."]. ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' 160: 598-598.</ref><ref>[[Peter J. Bowler|Bowler, Peter J]]. (2009). ''Science for All: The Popularization of Science in Early Twentieth-Century Britain''. University Of Chicago Press. p. 281. {{ISBN|978-0226068633}}</ref>
Beadnell was born in [[Rawalpindi]]. He was educated at [[Cheltenham College]] and studied medicine at [[Guy's Hospital]]. He was a Fellow of the [[Chemical Society]] and of the [[Royal Anthropological Institute]].<ref name="Nature"/> A rationalist and [[Skepticism|sceptic]], he was president of the [[Rationalist Association|Rationalist Press Association]] (1940-1947).<ref name="Nature"/><ref>Cooke, Bill. (2004). ''The Gathering of Infidels: A Hundred Years of the Rationalist Press Association''. Prometheus Books. p. 325. {{ISBN|978-1591021964}}</ref>
Beadnell described himself as a "devout [[Agnosticism|agnostic]]".<ref>Anonymous. (1947). [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2055821/pdf/brmedj03750-0035.pdf ''C. M. BEADNELL, C.B., M.R.C.S., L.R.C.P.]'' ''[[The BMJ|British Medical Journal]]'' 2 (4527): 591-592.</ref> He died in [[Petersfield, Hampshire]].
==Selected publications== * [https://archive.org/details/1920BeadnellRealityOrUnrealityOfSpiritualisticPhenomena ''The Reality or Unreality of Spiritualistic Phenomena: Being a Criticism of Dr. W.J. Crawford's Investigation into Levitations and Raps''] (1920) * ''A Picture Book of Evolution: Adapted from the Work of the Late Dennis Hird'' (1932) * ''Fireside Science'' (1934) [with [[Ray Lankester]]] * [https://archive.org/details/dictionaryofscie00bead ''Dictionary of Scientific Terms, as Used in the Various Sciences''] (1938) * ''The Origin of the Kiss and Other Scientific Diversions'' (1942) * ''An Encyclopaedic Dictionary of Science and War'' (1943)
==References== {{reflist}}
